newsitem.title: POLAND: FOCUS- AIB to take control of WBK.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS- AIB to take control of WBK.

text.p: Allied Irish Banks Plc (AIB) plans to take a majority state in Poland's Wielkopolski Bank Kredytowy SA (WBK) -- a regional bank that does similar business to its own, AIB's president said.

On Wednesday, AIB said it aimed to raise its 36.3 percent stake of WBK to a majority within three years from February 1997 by buying up to 23.9 percent of WBK currently held by the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD).
"Our intention would be to exercise the option (to acquire EBRD's stake)," Tom Mulcahy told a news conference.
Mulcahy said the two banks were compatible because they both were based in essentially agricultural regions where light industry dominated.
"We are quite confident about regional banks...because we believe that is where our strength as a company lies," he said. "We should not try to imitate other banks."
Mulcahy said AIB European Investment Ltd, a wholly-owned AIB subsidiary, which holds WBK's shares, had no immediate plans to buy other banks in the region.
Earlier on Wednesday, WBK and AIB also signed a letter of intent on setting up a trust fund corporation and an asset management company in Poland.
"We would like to begin a family of funds sometime next year, starting with a balanced fund," Justin Konieczny, adviser to WBK's president on investment banking, told Reuters.
The planned joint-venture, which will run the group of funds, will be fully owned by the asset management company, in turn equally owned by WBK and AIB.
WBK, based in the western Polish city of Poznan, is also interested in buying the central-bank-owned Polish Investment Bank SA (PBI) and Prosper Bank SA.
Jacek Ksen, president of WBK, told Reuters his bank was competing with four or five others to acquire both firms and WBK would make a detailed financial analysis of PBI and Prosper Bank in September.
"We can't make any decisions before a deep examination," Ksen said.
WBK had a net profit of 93.4 million zlotys over the first seven months of this year versus 59.5 million zlotys in the same period of 1995.
